passages.text: China (PRC) | Education
China East Education
Time to Take a BreatheG to Hold

CEE (China East Education) continues its strong comeback. We now forecast the company to resume almost peak operation efficiency in 2026. We also expect healthy FCF compounding from here. These has led us to increase 2025/26 net profit forecasts by \(34\% /40\%\) and PT to HKD8.8 (previously 6.6). Having said that, with the sharp increase in share price and some buyside investors' expectations, we recommend taking a breather here, and downgrade CEE's shares to Hold.

CEE's comeback after Covid disruptions. CEE faced two challenges after Covid: (1) Over- spending: CEE increased advertising to cover both on- line and off- line media. We believe even some of CEE's lower growth business units increased expenditure. (2) Competition: competition intensified as new competitors entered the vocational education industry to enjoy government subsidies. CEE management, upon noticing the issues in 2022, started to proactively tackle them. Management focuses more on the ROIC on marketing expenditures. By 2024, most of the low- ROIC campaigns had ended and were replaced by higher- ROIC marketing. We witnessed a meaningful recovery in CEE's margins. We believe CEE management has regained control of its marketing and client acquisition costs.

2026 outlook. We forecast 2026 sales to increase by \(10\%\) and net profit to increase by more than \(20\%\) YoY. This is driven by steady demand growth as well as good cost control (high school utilization, new regional centers optimizing cost and decent OPEX control).

(1) Enrollment healthy. We expect CEE to push more short-term products to echo China's policy (to upgrade the skill of Chinese workforce). It is also optimizing the long-tenure products, amid the intensifying competition from public schools.

(2) Costs and OPEX in check. CEE's regional composite teaching centers ensure better margins vs. its old smaller leased campuses. CEE's current campus utilization rate is approaching optimal levels (currently at \(70\%\) , optimal being \(80 - 90\%\) ). In addition, management now focuses on the ROIC of marketing, which helps to manage OPEX.

Revisions. We increase \(2025 / 26\) net profit forecasts by \(34\% /40\%\) , basically reflecting peak cycle performance of the business. We also forecast much stronger FCF generation as we reduce Capex (by assuming a better Capex efficiency). We increase our PT to HKD 8.8.

Take a breather. We believe the aforementioned improvements are well- embraced by the market, as evidenced by the strong share price performance YTD. However, we also detected elevated buyside expectations especially on CEE's top- line growth. We continue to argue that CEE is a good FCF compounding story and recommend investors to focus less on the short- term growth.
Please see analyst certifications, important disclosure information, and information regarding the status of non-US analysts on pages 4-9 of this report. \\* Jefferies Hong Kong Limited

We view China East Education as the leader in a vast private vocational education market. We expect China East Education to monetize the market by using methods and pace of growth that generate optimal ROIC. This could translate into steady and strong free cash flow.

Compared with consensus, we are more positive on the sustainability of growth in China East Education's FCF generation. We note that demand could be volatile, but we expect management to execute cash generation well.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

- Steady student growth in traditional categories due to reduced public funding for public vocational schools.- Efficient operations leading to strong free cash flow.- Profitable expansion in new categories.- Price target of HK\$8.80 based on DCF.

- Faster student growth in traditional categories, thanks to rapid market share expansion.- Efficient operations leading to strong free cash flow.- Profitable expansion in new categories.- Price target of HK\$11.00 based on DCF.

- Becomes more difficult to enroll students in traditional categories due to fierce competition.- Faces difficulties in maintaining good ROIC, capex and advertising expenditure.- Lack of profitable expansion in new categories.- Price target of HK\$6.60 based on DCF.

Top Material Issue(s): Sustainability Management is a key area of concern for China East Education across innovation, equality, green environment and society harmony. The co has built five systems to set a benchmark for vocational education: 1) education R&D, 2) entrepreneurship and employment guarantee, 3) teaching supervision, 4) professional accomplishment education, and 5) work- study combination education. It is also committed to protecting students' rights and interest in receiving education and offering a health and safe campus environment.
Company Target(s): Midterm (3- 5 years, based on 2021):

1. To increase food-waste recycling 
2. To improve utilization rate of waste resources and reduce (non-)hazardous waste 
3. To reduce vehicle greenhouse gas emissions and improve efficiency of energy use To enhance effectiveness of water resources use

1. What are quantitative targets on the environmental assessments? 
2. How much do you plan to invest in continuous development of the five systems over the short term and long term? 
3. How do you assess performance of the five systems each year?
- Enrollment data.- Shifting enrollment mix towards longer term.- Margin recovery in key businesses.- Successful addition of new brands.

China East EducationChina East Education and its subsidiaries are leading providers in vocational training education in China. Its business focuses on providing innovative vocational training education to students to increase their employability in the market.

We use DCF methodology as our primary approach to value the company's shares, as we expect investors to focus more on the company's long- term value creation. In our DCF model we derive a WACC of \(8.75\%\) , with cost of equity of \(9.5\%\) , risk- free rate of \(3.9\%\) , equity risk premium of \(5.6\%\) and beta of 1.0. We assume a perpetual growth of \(2.0\%\) , in line with our Hong Kong and China consumer sector at \(0 - 2\%\) .

Key downside risks: (1) weaker- than- expected new student enrollment leading to weaker school utilization rates, (2) more intense competition faced by Wontone and Omick, (3) new brands failing to deliver profitable growth, and (4) major change in Chinese government policy that reduces the demand for vocational education. Key upside risks: (1) stronger- than- expected new student enrollment leading to stronger school utilization rates, (2) easing competition faced by Wontone and Omick, (3) new brands delivering stronger profitable growth, and (4) much stronger- than- expected cost controls by management.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR)
Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\%\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\%\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated
securities with an average security price consistently below \(10, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus 20% or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
